Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They offer small gestures of kindness in daily interactions
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, my inbox overflowing with urgent messages. The launch date had been moved up, and now architects from three different teams were waiting on me to make decisions about the new features. My manager’s message was clear: “We need your input ASAP, everyone’s blocked.” I could feel the pressure mounting, my heart racing as I tried to juggle the technical details and the constant pings from frustrated colleagues. 

At the same time, I remembered the words from Sunday’s sermon—how we’re called to show love and kindness, even in stressful moments. I tried to offer small gestures: a patient reply, a word of encouragement, a willingness to listen. But as the demands piled up, I felt my patience thinning. I wanted to snap, to push back, to just get things done. Yet, I knew that wasn’t what I was called to do. The tension between being the efficient developer everyone needed and the compassionate Christian I wanted to be pulled at me, leaving me torn and uncertain about what to do next.
